awd_abstract_narration:
Nature encodes properties into large molecules, like DNA and proteins, by combining a set of building block molecules, called monomers, into specific sequences.  Spider silk protein, for example, derives its exceptionally tough nature from a specific sequence of amino acid monomers.  This model for controlling properties in large molecules like polymers has been difficult to emulate in non-biological materials, however, because of the challenge in preparing perfectly sequenced molecules of this type.  With the support from the NSF Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program, Professor Tara Meyer at the University of Pittsburgh conducts research to enhance our understanding of how precisely the sequence needs to be controlled to attain the desired polymer properties.  This work is expected to have a significant impact scientifically, technologically, and educationally.  The new synthesis method and the study of monomer sequence and their resultant properties represent a considerable scientific impact.  The demonstration that sequence need not be perfect to be useful could translate into the increased use of sequence in industrially-produced polymers, a potential technological benefit.  Finally, the involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in the research, with a particular emphasis on ensuring broad participation of trainees from all backgrounds, should contribute to a well-prepared scientific workforce.

The Meyer group has successfully prepared perfectly sequenced, biodegradable, non-toxic polymers called poly(lactic-co-glycolic acids)s (PLGAs) and demonstrated the dependence of their properties on sequence.  Unfortunately, the preparation of these perfectly sequenced PLGAs, and almost all other sequenced polymers, is too complicated and expensive to scale up for most applications.  The research team thinks that one way to address this barrier is to answer the following two questions: "Is it essential to have a perfect sequence?" and "Is it possible that a polymer with a sequence pattern that is 75% correct would be almost as high performing as a polymer whose sequence is 100% correct?"  The goal of this project is to address these questions by developing a new, more scalable method for preparing polymers with "just enough" sequence and then testing the properties of these semi-sequenced copolymers against perfect analogues.  A new parallel/successive synthetic strategy is introduced and developed with the goal of creating semi-sequenced step-growth copolymers with an intermediate level of control over monomer order. Inspired by the classic synthesis of polyurethanes, the parallel/successive strategy involves the creation, in parallel, of compositionally controlled pre-oligomers with similar backbones but differing sequences.  The successive reaction of these pre-oligomers produces semi-sequenced copolymers with a homogeneous composition in terms of the types of monomers present, but a segmented structure. Careful experimental design and the implementation of the method using a flow system can be implemented to yield materials with varying degrees of fine (monomer-by-monomer) and course (segment-level) sequence control.  The comparison of the properties of the semi-sequenced copolymers with those of the perfectly sequence materials improves the understanding of the various mechanisms through which sequence effects manifest.  Ultimately, this research may be translated into new technologies in advanced plastics and materials manufacturing.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Copolymers are plastics made from more than one monomer component are important materials for a wide range of technological and consumer applications. Although combining these monomer components in a specific sequence (like Nature employs in the synthesis of proteins) has the potential to produce materials with a wider range of tunable properties, the monomer components are more usually combined randomly because the random copolymers are much easier and less costly to produce.  The goal this project was to prepare and characterize semi-sequenced copolymers which are neither fully random nor perfectly sequenced with the goal of accessing the unique properties of sequenced copolymers with a more streamlined and practical synthesis.  To access these semi-sequenced structures,  a parallel-successive strategy was employed. The parallel-successive strategy involves first preparing shorter oligomeric building blocks in parallel and then combining them successively to make multiblock copolymers.  Three families of semi-sequenced copolymers were created:

1)      Biodegradable polyesters where pre-formed oligomers were combined using the same chemistry as was used to make the oligomers (Fig 1).

2)      Vinyl polymers prepared by the creation of oligomers which were then combined using an alternate chemical reaction (click reaction).

3)      Polycaprolactones prepared by creating diblock oligomers of substituted and unsubstituted caprolactones that were then combined using an alternated chemical reaction (metathesis). 

The other major outcome of this research was the development of two analytical methodologies to characterize the sequence patterns in the semi-sequenced copolymers.  This characterization is extremely challenging using standard spectroscopic tools. Method 1 involved the embedding of a cleavable unit in one of the monomers.  Post-polymerization digestion, selective for the cleavable unit, produced a set of oligomeric products whose chain-length and composition could be related to the original sequence pattern.  Method 2 involved the digestion of the biodegradable polyesters using a standard hydrolytic cleavage.  The exact pattern of this degradation, which depends on the number and types of connections, can be used to differentiate between sequences even if those sequences cannot be precisely characterized. 

Broader Impacts: The research performed in this project has impact in several areas: 1) Scientific, in the development of digestion techniques that are applicable to non-biological polymers to determine sequence; 2) Technologically, in that the creation of polymers with limited sequence control offers a practical method of introducing sequence patterns into copolymers which may lead to improved properties; 3) Educationally, both graduate (seven) and undergraduate students (two) were involved in the research and will go on to participate in the STEM workforce; and 4) in broadening participation, as the PI has worked to broaden participation in chemistry through multiple mechanisms.  

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: Tara Y Meyer

Image
  • Fig. 1. Parallel synthesis of oligomers followed by successive coupling of the oligomers to give a polyester. Double bonds are embedded in the polymer for subsequent digestion.
    Tara Meyer
    Copyrighted
    Tara Y Meyer
    Parallel-Successive Synthesis of Polyesters
